title: The national DNA database and newspaper debate in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland 1991-2008
abstractText:
While there is a growing academic and journalistic literature on the nature and extent of surveillance practices in the UK, there is little analysis of the heated public debate that has accompanied increasing use of surveillance.

The purpose of this research is to understand and explain the different positions taken by competing political actors with reference to the growth of the controversial national DNA database in the UK.

  • What are the arguments presented for and against the use of the database?
  • How have they changed over time?
  • How are these arguments distributed across the UK national press?
  • How have political actors sought to intervene in the public debate to influence public opinion?

These questions will be answered through undertaking a content analysis of newspapers and through interviewing the political actors present in the newspaper discourse.
